Hidangan berulat [METROTV]
06 Nov 2019, 18:14 by Noor Hidayah Tanzizi



“SAYA tiada niat jahat dan hanya mahu memberi peringatan kepada orang lain supaya lebih berhati-hati kerana ia membabitkan makanan,” kata Wan Mohd Amirul Wan Mohd Azam.
Wan Mohd Amirul, 24, adalah individu yang memuat naik video yang memaparkan mee segera goreng ayam berulat di sebuah restoran di Seri Manjung yang tular hari ini.
Menurutnya, kejadian itu berlaku kepada rakannya 5 pagi tadi dan merakam video berkenaan sebelum dikongsi dengannya di WhatsApp.
“Rasanya mee segera tiada masalah cuma ulat dari ayam yang dipercayai sudah beberapa hari, nasib baik dia belum sempat menjamah hidangan itu.
“Rakan sudah memaklumkan kepada orang kedai berkenaan dan perkara ini tidak sepatutnya berlaku kerana peniaga tidak mementingkan kebersihan makanan,” katanya ketika dihubungi hari ini.
Menurutnya, dia mengambil inisiatif berkongsi video berkenaan di Facebook (FB) kerana mahu orang ramai lebih berhati-hati dan baginya jika perkara itu didiamkan saja dibimbangi berulang lagi.
“Sebelum ini sudah ada berita keluar mengenai kedai makan kotor tetapi pengusaha makanan seperti tidak ambil kisah dan masih ada menjual makanan kitar semula.
“Jadi saya fikir ini untuk peringatan semua lagipun ia berlaku kepada kawan saya dan berharap pihak berkuasa dapat mengambil tindakan sewajarnya,” katanya.


Notis penutupan restoran yang didakwa menjual makanan berulat hari ini. FOTO Ihsan Pembaca

Sementara itu, Pengarah Kesihatan Perak, Datuk Dr Ding Lay Ming berkata, pihaknya tidak menerima aduan rasmi daripada pihak terbabit bagaimanapun mengambil maklum video yang tular itu.
“Setakat ini tiada aduan rasmi tetapi ia tular dalam media sosial dan pihak kami sedang menyiasat perkara ini,” katanya.
Tinjauan di kedai makan terbabit mendapati premis itu sudah diarah tutup oleh pihak berkuasa selama 14 hari bermula 4.30 petang hari ini sehingga 20 November ini namun usaha mendapatkan komen pemilik kedai tidak berhasil kerana tiada di premis.


Hidangan yang didakwa berulat oleh pelanggan di sebuah restoran. FOTO Ihsan Pembaca

Spicy dishes [METROTV]
06 Nov 2019, 18:14 by Noor Hidayah Tanzizi



"I have no malice and just want to warn others to be more careful because it involves food," said Wan Mohd Amirul Wan Mohd Azam.
Wan Mohd Amirul, 24, was the person who posted a video showing the instant noodle fried chicken at a restaurant in Seri Manjung today.
He said the incident happened to his friend 5am this morning and recorded the video before sharing it with him on WhatsApp.
"It feels like no problem with just the chicken from the chicken which is believed to have been gone for a few days, fortunately he has not been able to taste the dish.
"A friend has informed the store that this should not happen because the traders do not care about food hygiene," he said when contacted today.
He said he took the initiative to share the video on Facebook (FB) because he wanted the public to be more careful and for him to keep quiet about it again and again.
“There have been news outlets about dirty eateries but food vendors like to ignore and still sell recycled foods.
"So I think this is to remind all of the songs that happened to my friend and hope that the authorities can take appropriate action," he said.


Notice of closure of restaurant allegedly selling seafood today. Photo courtesy of Readers

Meanwhile, Perak Health Director Datuk Dr Ding Lay Ming said he had not received any formal complaints from the parties but was aware of the infectious video.
"So far there has been no official complaint but it has been trending on social media and we are investigating this matter," he said.
A survey of the eateries revealed that the premises had been closed by the authorities for 14 days from 4.30pm today until November 20, but attempts to obtain the store owner's comments were unsuccessful.
